I confirmed the member of Confederation of Koreans Living in Japan though I was watching by the live stream.
Because the public peace police also had been taking a picture with the video camera, it is likely to have confirmed it surely.

You assume "China is the biggest concern" and the need to "oppose China" as if its for granted, never mind the fact that we think China is the biggest concern precisely because of what you called "squabbles over little rocks" with our "allies". It's a circular reasoning. It's easy to play the China threat theory, but the bottom line is, China and the US has no conflict of core interest to be hostile to one another. Yet our international peace efforts from Ukraine, Syria, Iran and even Korea will all require China's cooperation and even collaboration. They may still be call communist today, but they are even more practical than we are with their policy.

The territorial disputes between China and surrounding nations have long been disputed even before the communist party came along; they did not just make it up out of thin air. For us to pick sides and give too much confidence to our allies in the pacific is also disestablishing. It is much better to stick to what we did for decades, stay clear of the disputed islands while staying committed to our allies.

I am very much a realist, but what we considered as preventative measures are interpreted by China as aggression and vice versa. There is no need to escalate it any further.

China is in economic trouble, and things are getting worse. The young adults walking from one factory town to the next may now number in the low millions, and the imbalance of gender means that hundreds of thousands of young men will never marry unless something big happens.

Meanwhile, Red China has stolen perhaps $5 to 6 billion in weapons design date, including the F-35 Lightning down to the last fastener, and many current drone aircraft.

Why bother to steal all this tech unless you are planning to use it? The are quite proud of their anti-ship missiles and these may be good enough to force U.S. carrier battle groups to stay hundreds of miles away from hostilities.

China - or someone - has already mounted attacks of private software outfits in our Silicon Valley and its energy grid. You'd think the news media were re-creating Tom Clancy's last novel.
The most glaring occupation dating from WWII is the Russian occupation and buildup on the Sakhalin chain.

Our decision to "welcome" this move is shortsighted and single-minded. We put all our attention to contain China, we forgot the message that we are sending to the entire Asia Pacific. Japan, arguably the most technologically advance and capable navy in Asia, can indeed augment the US navy in a potential combat, but it does come at a cost. There are still territorial dispute between Korea, Taiwan, China and Japan. All parties see Japan as an aggressor who still occupied some islands they took during imperial era. Is it worth the cost to anger all the others?

On top of that, while we insist our policy does not intend to contain China, for all intent and purposes, all the allies who cooperated with us in the region see our pivot to Asia as a way to contain China. Welcoming this change is clearly a step that will anger China but we do it anyway. Before we accuse China of being paranoid, perhaps we should take a look at our questionable policy.

comments.commentBody: It's true that chocolate in itself contains plenty of sugar and a little bit of vanilla, and also that you can make perfect ganache with nothing more than chocolate and cream. I wanted our recipe to have plenty of flavor range, so I experimented with different additions. Extra vanilla, to my palate, made a rounder-flavored ganache. The extra sugar is there because much of the "dark" chocolate on the market these days has a pronounced bitterness, and more sweetness helps balance that out. I like using coffee because it is non-alcoholic, but as it says in the recipe, it's entirely optional.

Thank you for your civilized response to my overly acerbic comment. I spent my childhood in Berkeley and went to Cocolat (Alice Medrich's store) whenever I had the chance; when I moved away I bought her book so I could make my own truffles. I'm sure your recipe is delicious, and it seems like it would do a better job doing double duty as hot fudge than a traditional ganache would. I will try it sometime, but will wait for slightly cooler weather....

I don't understand this recipe - why add sugar and vanilla when both of those ingredients are well represented in the chocolate itself? As for the coffee, I find that a coffee liqueur or extract works better than actual brewed coffee, which, no matter how strong you make it, is going to add more water than flavor. And salt is better sprinkled on the finished ganache than cooked into it. All you really need for this is the best chocolate you can find and cream - though if you're making truffles a few tablespoons of unsalted butter will help give it that dense, crumbly texture that echoes its fungal namesake.

Re: "...provide a means of creating rational incentive to invest more in a rational way."

I disagree.

Interest rates are already at or near zero, and lots of cash is parked in assets which return almost nothing after inflation.

This is evidence that there are virtually no viable opportunities for profitable investment, due to lack of demand.

Force feeding the economy from the investment side, is a misguided policy prescription, born of a supply-side worldview. Yes, investment is one component of demand. However, it is a component of demand which will be readily forthcoming, if the other components of demand are increased.

During the Great Depression, Ben Bernanke lived near a shoe factory, which was closed down, since no one had money to buy shoes. Was the answer to that problem, to force investors to build more shoe factories? Or was the correct solution to provide people with enough money to buy shoes?

It should be obvious that investors will try to grow and preserve their assets any way they can. Attempts to force investors to build unneeded factories, shops, apartments, or other goods, is misguided, and could just as easily result in asset bubbles in stocks, gold, oil, land, food, etc.

Higher wages and fiscal stimulus are the answers.
